newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asian electronics exports expected to recover.
newsitem.headline: Asian electronics exports expected to recover.

text.p: Asia's electronics exports are likely to recover towards year end as U.S. semiconductor orders stabilise and underlying demand remains strong, J.P. Morgan said in a research note on Friday.
It said the electronics slump had only really hurt a few countries in Asia, namely Korea, Singapore and to a lesser extent, Taiwan.
"In the rest of Southeast Asia, where production of semiconductors is small, the impact of the electronics slump has been minor," it said.
Electronics exports had continued to surge in the Philippines and to "rise solidly" in Indonesia and Thailand, the note added.
Recovery was imminent given that growth in U.S. demand for computers and other electronics equipment containing semiconductors had remained strong.

J.P. Morgan added, however, that excess capacity remained a problem in Asia, as Singapore and Taiwan had been expanding their capacities rapidly and Malaysia and the Philippines planned to build large semiconductor plants.
It said excess supply would keep prices and profit margins under pressure, especially in countries concentrating on basic electronic components.
